title: Are students with high grades more intelligent? - Quora

response.answer_text: They might or might not be. The first is the student. Some intelligent students get bored and become lazy, and might do very poorly in school if not given proper motivation and a good challenge. Other factors can also cause poor performance, such as bullying, abuse, personality conflict with the teacher, an incompetent teacher, or factors not related directly to the school. A student might also skip a year or two, and be doing work ahead of what would be his grade level. Then there is the teacher. In the same school, some teachers’ classes are easier to get good grades than others. Some are known as “easy ‘A’ classes/teachers” and other pride themselves in rarely giving an “A.” Some teachers teach better than average, maybe far better than average, and there are some who are not effective at teaching their subjects. Good, average, and bad teachers might be very strict in grading or very lenient in grading. Some might try to help a student succeed while others intentionally try to stop them from succeeding. Another is the school. Some schools are better than others. Some have more difficult work and higher standards. It is not unusual for some private schools to have students doing work 2–3 years ahead of typical public schools. The same student might get straight “A”s in a public school will likely get a lower GPA in a private school with harder work and higher standards unless he works much harder. Then there are the classes and subjects themselves. Some are more difficult than others. Combining a few of these factors, a student who should be a freshman could have skipped a hear and then gone to a tough private school as a sophomore could enroll in classes usually taken by juniors and seniors. He’d have a more difficult time getting the same grade than he would have if he stayed in his age group and in a typical public school. Grades don’t really reflect intelligence, and don’t really reflect learning either. In the case of learning, it is very common for people to get good grades in classes and then not be able to discuss the topic only a few years later. Even intelligent people can do this.

No. But they may be the more studious depending on subject. “Smart” needs proper definition so for this answer I will write quote generically. Anecdotally… (I have taught hundreds of students)… In any classroom there is a bell-curve. The ones between 1 and 2 standard deviations to the right of average will do best. Too far to the right, and the pace Of the class and its ability to keep the interest of the student is not a fit. On the left-side there is much effort involved and maybe 1 std Dev to the left and the subject is not well-understood viscerally. That does not mean that a less than average student in intellect cannot do well, they can and will with determination. Finally, there is still the question of whether “smart” is in anyway relevant to a classroom. Some of the smartest people I know by most counts are intelligent enough but have other non-academic skills that make us respect them and create their “smart” success-factors.

They can be. But this is not a necessity. For one thing, intelligent how? In what? In Math? English? Science? History? Shop class? We are not all good in the same thing. Some are good at learning. Poor at doing. A few years ago, I worked for an HVAC dealer. A young man with a learning disability was trying to become an apprentice. He had a HELLA awful time with the written study material. I tried to help him. See I can read, study, recall. He had issues here. But DOING? Here, he was a winner. As my boss said: We should let you study and go take the test. But if I needed a furnace or AC maintained, fixed, or installed, you would be the last guy I would pick for that. See? He, was a doer. Me, a learner. It the test is climbing a tree, the monkey wins. The fish, is an idiot. If the test is swimming in a river, the monkey drowns. The fish keeps on trucking. So, yes, they can be. But just because Bob can bang out an essay, and you cannot, that tells us little about your brains or abilities.

It is common to talk about children's intelligence & intellectual achievements in term of high grades, ranks, and numbers, and scholastic pursuits as reading, writing, studying or likewise. As far as measuring children's intelligence with high grades is concerned, it has two dimensions. Yes, it does matter. Second, it is not entirely dependent on it, it is only one part or phase of education. Intelligent includes the scholastic achievements, no doubts but not confined to it. Mental growth of the child is not solely dependant upon his pursuits in school. He learns immensely more from the home and other informal agencies of education. Children's poor grades are not a problem, because sometimes bad grades are related to lack of interest and attention rather than intelligence. Therefore, to choose the right field based on their individual abilities and interests is a great problem for them so that they can provide better results.

In my minimally experienced opinion it really depends on either parents or priority. There are kids I’ve known who have been threatened to get good grades or they will be punished in an assortment of ways, they chose the latter. Obviously. But personally I haven’t gotten good grades since 4th grade, (3yrs ago) thats simply because I don’t really care. It doesnt matter to me. Kids bragging about their GPA being 3.5 doesn’t bother me, doesn’t make me jealous, it just annoys me. Some think its a bragging matter, most think of it as a personal thing, gladly. But with my astonishing GPA of 2.61 because I don’t bother with school. I sleep through about a quarter of every class, other than that I pay attention but don’t do projects nor homework tests are the only reason I have even semi-high grades.

High grades do not always equate to a high level of intelligence. I will try to keep my answer fairly short. There are people that can be called letter hunters or in my case with the IB system, number hunters. These people only do the minimum amount of work required to get an A. It means that they are smart at coming up with answers for certain things but does not mean that they are highly intelligent. Another kind of example would be looking at someone conducting a research project and a test. The person may be able to receive an A for the research but a C for the test. They know how to use their resources to get information but do not necessarily know that information and come up with their conclusions. Catch my drift?

Good question. You can't say that students with high grades are more intelligent or have good IQ. This totally depends on the student. Nowadays if there's survey among high grades students, we'll find that most of them will have only theoretical or bookish knowledge but they hardly know about practical knowledge. We see most of the colleges or schools doesn't provide proper practical classes. If they do, most of the students just mug those up rather than knowing its actual applications. I can say ‘a single piece of paper cannot decide your intelligence’. I didn't mean to say that students should only have practical knowledge but knowing both the concepts (practical as well as theoretical) will make you a good student. Having good grades is a very nice thing. You should have good grades. But knowing those things practically will make you good at another level.

Probably but not definitely. Having good grades means that you have spent time learning something and that you learned it well. This is either a result of discipline or, more likely, this is because they can learn something without getting frustrated or stuck. It is easy for them to learn and maybe even enjoyable. This ease of learning can be said to stem from intelligence. It is likely that someone who is good at basketball to enjoy it better than someone who is bad at it; this makes it easier to practice and get better. Same thing goes for studying and performance at school.

Certainly not. Too often, students with high grades are really good at parroting. They know just what to do to get the grades. That is a skill, to be sure. But it’s not the ultimate goal of education. Let’s not forget: many students with great grades take adderall and ritalin to keep their performance up. They succeed, too. Yet, life is more than this struggle to be the one with an impressive grade sheet. Students with grades may be extremely smart, but they are doing themselves a disservice by defining success in such narrow terms.

Usually students with higher grades are better test takers and since the IQ is calculated via a similar test, those students with High IQs often have high grades, but not every student with high grades has a high IQ. Likewise, there are people with a high IQ that are not great test takers. I for one do great on IQ tests, but did not do as well on the standardized tests such as SATs. I still scored 1280 out of 1600 but nowhere near as high as my IQ results.

Per my observation, no. High grades require consistency, and a lot of times doing things that aren’t as much challenging but rather routine. Students with “high intelligence” tend to easily get bored with the routine and only focus on issues that interest them. From my experience, students with high grades, in most cases, have been the guys who aren’t as “intelligent” as those guys, but have generated superb work ethic to achieve the goal of high grades. But the answer largely depends on how you define intelligence.

I know of two Nurses ( RNs), and one Dr, who scored 100% in the case of the Nurses, and one Dr who was so useless it was surreal but the Dr's marks were high. In all 3 cases, they quite literally a danger to their patients, but they functioned a bit like HOUSE in the TV series, i.e. great at diagnostics, but absolutely abysmal at practical. One of the RNs became super qualified, and was a supervisor of a brain trauma unit ( nice pay too), and the Dr became an in house Dr at a University clinic for students, where 99% of her work was referring to other Docs. All of these 3, had near perfect photographic style recall of facts, but applying the knowledge was just beyond them. I know some of the history of the Dr, and the "funniest" was after a patient started cynaosing ( turning blue), the Dr ran out of the ward screaming, so the nurses worked on the patient and saved the patient, and the screaming event was hushed up. So, basically, you can be great in theory, but not necessarily in practice. In my view, the best way to be is to know your strong points and where your intelligence works best. Focus on what you do best, and realize that the reverse is true, someone can be great at practice but awful at exams. Each intelligence has a place, just know your skill-set.

Hi Hugo, not necessarily … You have students prepared to product confetti with a hole puncher for a good grade and that is far from being intelligent but many times works … Tests during education don’t measure intelligence they simply show how well the person taking the test answered that particular day. You can cheat for good grades, too. Higher grades just show, that the student answered or produced what was expected - but not how they did it …

In my opinion, no. The smartest usually are bored with basic of the task given, it seems soooo simple! so they are busy doing something else and of course are not ready on time. They can obtain highest grades, when are interested, involved in obtaining best results. High grades are for ambitious, determined, but also compliant, scrupulous, not necessarily the most talented or clever

A student with high grades is intelligent in the domain where he has high grades. A student who does not have high grades: you don’t know. He can be sick, poorly trained, suffer from the physical ailment you do not know (it is not rare to discover at college level that a student is half deaf or half blind), have no interest in the subject…

In a way yes but no I'll explain. They have smarter work ethic and try harder than people who get average grades so this makes them smarter however, the only think that's stopping people with average grades to get higher grades is their work ethic.

No . Especially in middle school they are actually stupid.They are thinking that way that “daddy will buy me something if i get an A.They are not realizing that they are getting brainwashed with learning unneeded thinks they learn in school.

Original question was: “Do you agree that the ones who obtain high grades are always the smartest?” No. They’re the ones who do something called “study.” As I discovered about 40 years ago when I changed my attitude my junior year at Texas A&M University. I went from being an average student to being an “A” student just by changing my attitude and studying hard. Anyone can do it if they are really determined.

Definitely not. Grades are dependent on students turning in work to be graded. A highly motivated, organized and hard working student can make much better grades than a super smart student that has poor study habits.

Not necessarily. But they tend to be more diligent and disciplined. Many very intelligent people don’t have the self-discipline to get the best grades, and many don’t even realize they are intelligent, because of psychological issues, or poverty, among other things.
No.
